projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: A PROCLAMATION For providing Magazines of Corns, Hay and Straw, to Their Maje≈øties Troops.

opener.signed: WILLIAM and MARY, by the Grace of GOD, King and Queen of Great-Britain, France and Ireland, Defenders of the Faith;
opener.salute: To Our Lovits, „Äà1 span left blank„Äâ Macers of Our Privy Council, Me≈ø≈øengers at Arms, Our Sheriffs in that part, conjunctly and ≈øeverally, ≈øpecially Con≈øtitute, Greeting:

div.p: We taking into Our Royal Con≈øideration, the great and many Inconveniencies, which Our Troops, as well as the Countrey, do, or may ≈øu≈øtain, in ca≈øe Provi≈øions and Stores of Corn, Hay and Straw, he not timou≈øly and orderly made, at the re≈øpective Burghs and Places, where Our Forces ≈øhall be Quartered. Therefore We, with the Advice of the Lords of Our Privy Council, Require and Command, the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Supply, or the plurality of ≈øuch of them as ≈øhall conveen, conform to the 6th Act, 3d Se≈ø≈ø. of Our fir≈øt Parl. within the ≈øeveral Shires, where any of the Troops of Our Forces, Hor≈øe, or Dragoons ≈øhall happen to be Quartered, to meet each fir≈øt and third Tue≈ødays of every Moneth, during the continuance of the Forces in the ≈øaids Shires, and to appoint rea≈øonable prices of Corns, Hay, and Straw, at which the ≈øame ≈øhall be ≈øold and furni≈øhed; And We with Advice fore≈øaid, Require and Command the ≈øaids Commi≈ø≈øioners, to Ordain the Collectors of Supply, within the ≈øeveral Shires of this Kingdom, upon a competent allowance for their pains, to provide, buy up, and furni≈øh, where they can be≈øt have it for ready Money, (to be payed by them out of the Ce≈øs of the ≈øaids ≈øhires, received by the ≈øaid Collector) ≈øufficient Magazins of Corn, Hay, and Straw, for the ≈øpace of fourteen dayes, at the ≈øeveral Burghs of the ≈øaids Shires, for the number of Hor≈øes quartered, or to be quartered upon them, and in the pre≈øent Service of the ≈øaids Officers, Troopers, or Dragoons them≈øelves; with Certification, that if any Hor≈øe not pre≈øently in their Service, ≈øhall be intertained upon the ≈øaid Magazin, the Hor≈øe ≈øhall be Confi≈øcat, and the Officer, Trooper, or Dragoon, in who≈øe Name he is intertained, ≈øhal be Ca≈øhired, and turned out of the ≈øaid Troop, and ≈øo from time to time, during the continuance of their Quarters at that place: And We Declare, That what Provi≈øions have been, or ≈øhall be furni≈øhed by the ≈øaids Collectors, forth of the for≈øaids Magazines, to the Officers or others of Our Forces, and ≈øhall be unpayed by them, the ≈øame ≈øhall be allowed to the ≈øaids Collectors, and retained by them, out of the fir≈øt end of the Ce≈øs, due and payable by the ≈øaids Shires, conform to the Receipts thereof granted to them by any Trooper or Dragoon, or any of their Officers, conde≈øcending upon the Names of the ≈øaids Officers, Troopers, or Dragoons, and upon the Troop and Regiment, to which they do belong; And the ≈øaids Officers are hereby Required from time to time, to call ≈øuch of their ≈øaids Troopers as cannot Write, before them≈øelves, and in their Names grant Receipts to the Collector for what hath been or ≈øhall be delivered by him to them, out of the ≈øaids Magazines, under the Certification above-written. And We, with Advice fore≈øaid, Do hereby peremptorly Command and Require, the General Receivers of the Ce≈øs and Supply, to allow to the Collectors fore≈øaids, what ≈øhall be in≈øtructed to be given out by them in the terms above-written, in the fir≈øt end of the Ce≈øs and Supply of the Shire, where the ≈øaids Provi≈øions have been, or ≈øhall be made, and to receive the ≈øaids Receipts from the Collectors in the ≈øeveral Shires, as ≈øufficient exoneration to them of the Ce≈øs of the Shire pro tanto, and only Order Quartering for what ≈øhall be re≈øting by the ≈øaids Shires, after the ≈øaids Magazines and Provi≈øions are allowed, under the pain of being deprived of their Offices as General Receivers in all time coming, and the Premi≈ø≈øes to be ob≈øerved as the Rule of providing, and furni≈øhing ≈øuch of Our Forces, as are upon the Scots E≈øtabli≈øhment; and as to the≈øe of Our Forces which are upon the Engli≈øh Pay, We with Advice fore≈øaid, Ordain the Collectors fore≈øaids of the re≈øpective Shires, to furni≈øh them forth of the ≈øaids Magazines, upon their making payment by ready Money for what they ≈øhall receive at the rea≈øonable prices fore≈øaids, to be ≈øet down or appointed by Our ≈øaids Commi≈ø≈øioners of Supply in the ≈øeveral Shires, as ≈øaid is, and no otherwi≈øe. And to the effect Our Plea≈øure in the Premi≈ø≈øes may be known, Our Will is herefore, and We Charge you ≈øtraitly and Command, that incontinent, the≈øe Our Letters ≈øeen, ye pa≈øs to the Mercat-Cro≈øs of Edinburgh, and to the Mercat-Cro≈ø≈øes of the whole remanent Head-Burghs of the ≈øeveral Shires within this Kingdom, and there, in Our Name and Authority, by open Proclamation, make Publication of the Premi≈ø≈øes, that none may pretend ignorance, as ye will an≈øwer to Us thereupon; The which to do, We commit to you, conjunctly and ≈øeverally, Our full Power, by the≈øe Pre≈øents delivering them by you, duly Execute, and Indor≈øed again to the bearer.
div.closer:
Given under Our Signet at Edinburgh, the twelfth day of December, And of Our Reign the ≈øecond year, 1690.
Per actum Dominorum Secreti Concilii. D A. MONCREIFF, Cls. Sti. Concilii.
GOD ≈øave King William and Queen Mary.
